docs.title: Activation of the repository
docs.text: Here you have a detail guide to install and use the repository

docs.title: 1. Clone the repository
docs.text:
cd ../working_folder
git clone https://github.com/giovanniminuto/my-py-template.git
cd my-py-template

# activate you favorite IDE 
# Es: VS Code 
code .

docs.title: Note:
docs.text:
• This is a good time to rename the project from my-py-template to your desired project name. You can find all occurrences of the template name in tracked files with: 
    git grep -niE "my[-_]py[-_]template"
    where:
    • git grep - Print lines matching a pattern, documentation link
    • -n prints matches along with the line number inside each file.
    • -i makes the search case-insensitive
    • -E enables extended regex -> regex code [-]: means “either a dash (-) or an underscore ()”.

And all the file name contains the template name 

git ls-files | grep -iE "my[-_]py[-_]template"
- - git ls-files - Show information about files in the index and the working tree, documentation link - - -i makes the search case-insensitive - - -E enables extended regex -> regex code [-]: means “either a dash (-) or an underscore ()”.

  • If you want to copy the files into an existing repository, check out this practical guide on StackOverflow.

docs.title: 2. Create a virtual environment
docs.text:
python -m venv .venv
The .venv/ folder is ignored by Git by default. If you change the environment folder name, update .gitignore accordingly. Activate the environment: - Linux/macOS 
source .venv/bin/activate
- Windows (PowerShell) 
.venv\Scripts\Activate.ps1

docs.title: 3. Install dependencies
docs.text:
Install project dependencies: 

pip install -e .
ℹ️ Requires pip >= 21.3 The default dependencies include Qadence (link) and Jupyter Notebook support. You can edit them under [project.dependencies] in pyproject.toml.

Install the optional dependencies to use pre-commit/pytests/mkdocs: 

pip install -e ".[dev,docs]"

docs.title: 📂 Project Structure
docs.text:
Now everything is set up, and you can start adding your source code inside:

  • my_py_template/ → your main source code
  • examples/ → example scripts that use your source code

docs.title: Here the last info to run properly the Pre-commit, Tests and Docs
📖 Documentation
docs.text:
Build documentation locally with: 

mkdocs serve
Then open http://127.0.0.1:8000.

Validate documentation build (strict mode): 

mkdocs build --clean --strict

docs.title: ⚙️ CI/CD
docs.text:
This template includes a ready-to-use GitHub Actions workflow for:

  • Linting & testing
  • Building documentation
  • Optional deployment to GitHub Pages

See .github/workflows/ci.yml.
